title: plans-for-new-clubhouse-hotel-and-houses-at-dunbar-golf-club-set-to-be-submitted-this-summer
story: Discussions about a new clubhouse and hotel at the historic course, which dates back to , have been ongoing for more than a decade.Earlier this year, Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd, who are behind the plans, revealed updated proposals, which also include about  homes.A public exhibition was held at the end of April ahead of a formal planning application being submitted in ldquolate summer early autumn.Tony Thomas, from APT Planning and Development Ltd, is representing the two organisations and was pleased to say more than  people had visited the public exhibition.The plans, as well as including a modern clubhouse and hotel, also feature a new driving range, nine-hole golf course, a golf academy and practice facilities.Mr Thomas said the general reaction towards the images of the proposed clubhouse was ldquobrilliant, with many asking when it would open.Concerns focused on public access versus membersrsquo rights, with a general concern about the level of development throughout the town.Mr Thomas stressed that plans for a development on the site dated back several years, with older proposals having been given the green light in .The new proposals, which will not impact on the future of the existing course, were building on the previously approved plans.Mr Thomas previously outlined the hope that a planning application could be with the local authority by September.If approved, the first houses would be built a year later, with the clubhouse built in  and opening the following year.About  new homes would be built on the site of the current clubhouse, with the majority further south-east.

title: costa-coffee-in-musselburgh-criticised-for-overflowing-bins
story: Ward councillor Stuart Currie took up the issue after complaints from residents about the litter problem at the rear of the outlet opposite the entrance to Musselburgh Burgh Primary School.He branded it ldquounacceptable but the company has apologised to residents and pledged it has taken steps to address the issue.Mr Currie said: ldquoI was contacted by constituents about this issue and took it up with council officers.ldquoI was pleased about the swt action taken by our council staff to ensure that the problem has been dealt with in the short term.ldquoWhat is important is that Costa continues to ensure they apply the very best standards in our town.He added that there were bags full of Costa cups, adding: ldquoTrade waste bins are supposed to be sealed to stop people throwing things into them. Get another binitrsquos overflowing.Mr Currie said that the situation had improved and assurances had been given that it would not happen again.He said a similar issue was raised about a year ago andit happened a third time, formal action should be taken by the council against Costa.Mr Currie acknowledged that the coffee chain generated jobs locally and added to Musselburgh High Street.But he stressed: ldquoIt is their responsibility to ensure they clear up their trade waste adequately.The anti-litter campaign group Donrsquot Mess With Mussy is also calling on the company to clean up its act.Organiser Melanie Roccio said there were wooden drink stirrers, Costa-branded sugar packets and paper cups on the ground near the bins when they were not overflowing.She said: ldquoAs a huge brand name, Costa need to do so much more and they have the resources to do it.ldquoThe issue has been reported to them multiple times over three years.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have visited the location and stressed the need for arrangements to be made to clear the area. We understand a private waste contract is in place.ldquoWe will continue to monitor the situation.A Costa Coffee spokesperson said: ldquoAs the nationrsquos favourite coffee shop, we are continually working hard to ensure that we serve the needs of our local communities. We apologise to the local residents of Musselburgh and have taken the necessary steps to address this issue working alongside East Lothian Council.

title: section-a1-shut-overnight-week-roadworks
story: Maintenance work will be carried outovernight on the westboundA layby to Gladsmuir between pm and ameach nightfrom Sunday, July , till Sunday,August .A signed ersion will be in place.Traffic will exit the westbound A via Oaktree Junction westbound off-slip road to join the A and on to the B.From here, vehicles will travel to the westbound Gladsmuir Junction on-slip road to re-join the westbound A.This work, with a value of pound, will benefit around , vehicles using this routeeach day by improving the condition of the carriageway and reducing the need for further more extensive maintenance, said Amey, which is responsible for maintaining the A.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services, Lothian Buses and East Lothian Council.

title: popular-teacher-retires-ross-high-school
story: Gordon Muchall, an additional support needsteacher at the Tranent secondary school, has been praised for his work encouraging outdoor education and giving young children new and positive opportunities.From Edinburgh, Gordon followed a dferent path to most teachers, having been a partner in a law firm and a Catholic priest before giving it up and following a career in teaching.He said: ldquoIt felt like quite a natural progression. I had a broad range of experiences to bring to the job.ldquoWhen I was a priest, I was chaplain at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, dealing with people who were grieving, and I also visited special needs schools in Fe, and it was these visits that got me into teaching.ldquoLeaving the priesthood was a decision that I thought long and hard about, and in the end decided that it was the right move and I have no regrets. I trained as a teacher and got a job at Ross High over nine years ago.ldquoI was keen to bring a lot of outdoor learning to my work. I encouraged the children to climb hills, try kayaking and canoeing, rugby, things that a lot of the parents never thought their children could do.ldquoIrsquom a rugby referee as well, so naturally encouraged the children to play rugby, and to join the school choir and things.ldquoSeeing how happy they were and the smiles on their faces is something that I will really miss.Gordon is planning to move to the Isle of Mull to spend his retirement with his we.ldquoWersquore quite outdoorsy, we do a lot of hiking and kayaking, he said.ldquoOur house will be right on the waterfront, so I am very looking forward to it.ldquoIrsquove enjoyed myself, but I think itrsquos time for younger blood to take over, and I can give myself a rest!Jillian Binnie, depute head teacher ASN at Ross High, said: ldquoGordon has made a huge contribution to the ASN provision and Ross High School as a community, especially in driving the introduction of an outdoor education programme that allows all of our young people, even those with the most severe and complex needs, to take part.ldquoHe has a calm, non-judgemental approach to dealing with any challenges he might face on a daily basis.ldquoHe shows all of our young people unconditional positive regard and has built strong relationships with both our young people and their families. He is also a much-valued team member.ldquoWe all wish him well in his retirement.

title: calls-create-car-park-aldi-moves-new-site-haddington
story: Aldi is among the businesses named in a planning application for a retail park on Haddingtonrsquos western edge.Those proposals are still being weighed up by the council but,approved, it could see Aldi move from its current home off Whittingehame Drive to the new development at Gateside West.That would leave an empty site, with community councillors in the town suggesting that the council look into creating a new town centre car park there.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of Haddington and District Community Council, was among those backing the idea.She said: ldquoThat would be a great thing to happen because we are needing the spaces.ldquoEast Lothian Council have bought [the hospital site at] Herdmanflat and,they can buy over that, I hope they would be able to buy Aldi, although I am surprisedAldi were moving.Concerns about town centre parking have been raised on a regular basis, with fears that there are not enough spaces to ensure people can use the townrsquos businesses.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, also felt it was worth weighing up the idea of transforming the site.He said: ldquoIf [the council] can buy it, that would be great.ldquoButsomebody is there saying it is a brand new shop and they can walk in, change the logo and open, they are going to put in a slightly higher bid than what the council can put in.Pat Lemmon, who works in the town centre, felt it was a good location for a potential car park.She said that changes planned for the town centre were suggesting parking spaces could be lost and an alternative ldquohad to be found.The community councillor told the Courier: ldquoI cannot see East Lothian Council giving up their car park or the long-stay car park at Tesco, which they seem to fill up first thing in the morning. Another car park has been mooted for a long time.However, echoing Mr Darlingrsquos view, she felt that it was more likely that another supermarket or retailer would move into the siteAldi decided to move.The town centre site has been home to a supermarket for more than  years, with Aldi setting up shop about a decade ago.When the plans for the retail park at Gateside West were lodged, the supermarket giants distanced themselves from any potential move, despite being named in the plans ndash along with coffee chain Costa and Home Bargains ndash as ldquoend occupiers confirmed for the site.A spokeswoman for Aldi said the new store was ldquonot currently on our radar.The Gateside development would be made up of three retail units, two restaurants cafes and a drive-thru takeaway, with Greggs and The Food Warehouse also linked.A petrol station and retail unit are also being earmarked for the site.Currently, the Aldi store site has more than  parking spaces but that number would increasethe supermarket building were demolished.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThese are speculative comments and we believe that Aldi has dismissed rumours that they may move location.ldquoIn general terms, any changes of use to sites within Haddington would be open to consultation with local residents and businesses.

title: new-museum-exhibition-celebrates-history-musselburgh-festival
story: Past Honest Lads and Honest Lasses have rallied round with support by donating items of memorabilia for the display, which includes photographs of past events, riding boots, stirrups and a riding crop.The iety of gts presented by local industries and the community to Honest Lads and Honest Lasses at sashing ceremonies can been seen, as well as trophies for events such as the Honest Ladsrsquo Race, Ladiesrsquo Race and Crusaders Riding Club competition.There is a chance to get a close-up look at sashes embroidered with the names of every Honest Lad and Honest Lass from  to  and the Burgh Standard, which plays an important role during the annual festival.Official outfits worn by the Honest Lad and Honest Lass are exhibited, as well as programmes, pennants, the first minute book for festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and words for the Musselburgh Song. Information is on show about the carriage used on election night, when the official party is transported through local streets to waving crowds.The birth of the festival in , when Jimmy Arthur was Honest Lad and Ina Vass, Honest Lass, is also outlined.This yearrsquos Honest Lad Aidan Maguire, Honest Lass Claire Dougal and attendant Abbie Thomson were amongst the first to enjoy a tour of the exhibition after their recent visits to local primary schools and Musselburgh Grammar School.Stefanie Talac, honorary secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association , said this was the first exhibition about the festival at the museum and they hoped that as many people as possible would pay it a visit.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the way the exhibition has turned out. We had a lot of help from past Honest Lads and Honest Lassies.ldquoThere is a beautully bound photograph album from the Honest Lass of  which was presented by the local paper mill. Our th year Honest Lass was presented with a travel iron from Brunton Wire Mill. The connection with the fishing community in Musselburgh is also shown in the gts with a ship in a bottle and model boats.She added: ldquoDuring the festival, the Honest Lass pins a pennant to the top of the flag and it has the Honest Ladrsquos name on it. Each pennant is in the museum as well.Stefanie said that while the festival is on from July  to  this year, some of the display items will be removed as they will have a part to play in the event itself, before being ed to the museum afterwards.She added: ldquoThe museum is a great asset to the town. We are really pleased that we have had the opportunity to have the exhibition in the museum. It is the first since the museumrsquos inception and hopefully we will do so again in the future. The exhibition is here for people who want to learn more about the festival and we hope they do.The museum at  High Street is open Thursday to Saturday, .am to pm.

title: parents-launch-petition-school-bus-operator-change
story: Families whose children attend two secondary schools in East Lothian were stunned to discover that local firm PrenticeCoaches would no longer be used to transport the youngsters when schoolsafter the summer.The news was broken to them by Prentice, which is based in Haddington, last week, sparking a furious reaction from a number of parents.Now a petition has been launched calling for Prentice to have the contract, which has allegedly been awarded to a rival firm, given back.One mother whose children attend Knox Academy in Haddingtonand are bussed in from Gford said that she was shocked by the news.She said: ldquoPrentice have been looking after our children for  years and they are being replaced with no consultation or discussion.ldquoParents know the drivers and trust them to look after their children.ldquoIt is beyond belief that the council would simply put a dferent company in place without even consulting with the families affected.A petition calling for theof Prentice has collected more than  signatures since it was launched online.It says: ldquoPrentice provide a community service where parents feel reassured and comfortable putting their children on the buses.ldquoWe believe East Lothian [Council] has chosen to put cost over service and safety.ldquoThere is absolutely nothing wrong with the current service.ldquoThis is simply a cost-cutting exercise which could potentially put our children at risk.Prentice provided bus services for Knox Academy and North Berwick High School but has now lost the contract for those services.Ross Prentice, the company boss, admitted that he was ldquodisappointed by the councilrsquos decision.The company said: ldquoIt is a sad day. We have operated the Knox routes continuously for over  years.ldquoWe would like to thank all the pupils and parents who we have transported over the years for being so friendly and their excellent behaviour, and wish the current pupils all the best for their futures.A spokesman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAs the previous contract had expired, the council was required to carry out an open procurement process to appoint an operator for the service.ldquoAs the contract is yet to be formally awarded, we cannot provide further detail at this stage.ldquoHowever, we can assure families that tenders have been assessed in line with all requirements, standard procedure and quality criteria. In the event of a new operator being appointed, other aspects of the service will be unchanged.The petition can be found at you.degrees.org.uk petitions reinstate-prentice-buses-as-knox-academy-school-transport-provider

title: bbc-show-broadcast-live-east-lothian-evening
story: Foxlake Adventures plays host to the BBC Scotland Adventure Show, which will be streaming live for only the second time ever from the wakeboarding park, near West Barns.The show, which starts at pm, is hosted by Dougie Vipond, Lauren MacCallum and Patrick Winterton.Paul McGreal, organiser, said: ldquoLeave the stresses and strains of the working week behind you and come and watch something fast and furious at the amazing Foxlake Adventures. This is off-road triathlon like yoursquove never seen it before!ldquoThe course will be short wersquore aiming for winning times of around - minutes. Yep, thatrsquos for the whole lot, swim, bike and run. So, they can take it as fast or as easy as they like. Either way, this should be fun.The course covers approximately m open-water swim in the private, freshwater wakeboard park, then a k mountain bike section and a k trail run.The BBC are inviting members of the public to cheer on the participants, though there will be no vehicle access after pm there is no charge.

title: popular-pub-set-huge-385k-revamp
story: The Cartvale, in Busby, is hoping to make a name for itself for having one of the best beer gardens in the area once work is complete.The makeover will get underway from July , with the venue scheduled to reopen in late August, creating  new jobs.:Glasgow restaurant giving away dining prizes to celebrate th birthdayFull redecoration of the outside of the building will accentuate its character on Main Street.The garden will also receive a makeover and become a focal point. New decking and planting, seating for  and festoon lighting will enhance its setting next to White Cart Water.The inside of the pub will be given a stylish look, including new folding windows and a balustrade to provide views over the river and woodlands.A kitchen will be put in to enable new licensee Andy Crossan, from the south of Glasgow, to introduce new food to the pub, all with a Scottish slant.How the pub will look upon completionAndy said he wants The Cartvale to be ldquoa hub of the community and welcoming to all.He will open it up to local groups and clubs in need of meeting space and host a range of activities from quiz and board game evenings to music nights featuring bands from Glasgow and the West of Scotland.Andy is also investing in Sky TV so local residents can enjoy major sporting events.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesHe said: ldquoIrsquove worked in hospitality all my le and have always wanted a pub of my own.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to work in a positive environment where you see people having a good time. title: theresa-may-successor-dont-trust-nicola-sturgeon
story: In a blunt message to Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister said the SNPcould not be relied upon to act in ldquogood faith.Warning "we do not have good will on all sides", she said the next occupant of Number  must actively strengthen the Union or it would be "too late".She said: ldquoOver the last three years I have learned that while other parties can be relied on to work with the UK Government in good faith to make devolution a success, an SNP Scottish Government will only ever seek to further the agenda of separation.ldquoThat, I am afraid, is simply a fact of political le in the UK at the moment."That fact puts an additional responsibility on the UK Government. If we do not do all we can to realise the full benefits of the Union ndash no one  will."If we do not use every policy lever within our reach to strengthen that Union ndash no one  will."Andwe do not make realising the full benefits of being a United Kingdom of four proud nations and one united people our priority now, then in the future it may be too late.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Theresa May: My successor in Number  will make protecting union top priority","description": "Theresa May: My successor in Number  will make protecting union top priority","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs rCGAFVF-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rCGAFVF.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": In her last official speech north of the border before her successor is named on July , Mrs May warned the next Prime Minister not to take the Union for granted, but actively promote and protect it from Nationalists working to bring about its end.She agreed with former Labour PM Gordon Brown that the UK was under threat.Describing Brexit as ldquoa profound constitutional change putting political and administrative strains on the Union, she said: ldquoWhen Gordon Brown recently said that he fears the Union is lsquomore imperilled now than it has ever beenrsquo he voiced the fears of many.ldquoI care passionately about our Union. I certainly do not underestimate the scale of the challenge it faces. But I am optimistic about its future.Mrs May was speaking to party activists in Stirling about strengthening the Union after  years of devolution, announcing a review of how UK Government departments could do so led by former Scotland Office minister Lord Andrew Dunlop.She said: ldquoToday, the only threat to devolution comes from those parties who want to end it by breaking up the United Kingdom.ldquoFor those of us who believe in the Union, devolution is the accepted and permanent constitutional expression of the unique multinational character of our Union.ldquoIt was ironic that the UK Governmentrsquos sincere efforts to ensure that Brexit had no unintended consequences for the UKrsquos internal market was dismissed as a lsquopower-grabrsquo by the SNP.ldquoA UK Government which had enthusiastically launched and implemented the Smith and Silk Commissions ndash transferring sweeping powers over tax and welfare - stood accused of using Brexit as the cloak behind which to claw-back powers over food labelling and fertiliser regulations. On one level the allegation is simply absurd.ldquoOn another, it highlights a challenge which faces the UK Government as it seeks to act in the best interests of the whole UK. Whereas the UK Government is invested in the success of devolution, it would suit the political aspirations of the present Scottish Government for devolution to fail, or to be seen to fail.She repeatedly cited the pledge by Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon that the  independence referendum would be a once in a generation or once in a letime decision.She said: ldquoIf a majority had supported independence, the UK Government would have accepted that result ndash no question. But the people of Scotland did not vote for independence.ldquoA clear and decisive majority of ten percentage points gave the Union their backing and their decision should be respected.ldquoSo when Nicola Sturgeon requested of the UK Government in  the power to legislate for a second independence referendum, just three years after that historic vote, I had no hesitation in firmly saying lsquonorsquo. In the future, it will be for others to decide based on the prevailing circumstances how to respond to separatism. But the principle is clear ndash the Union can and will only prosperit enjoys the support of its people.The speech was delivered on the eve of Mr Johnson and Mr Hunt appearing at the sole Scottish hustings in the Tory leadership contest in Perth tomorrow.Mr Johnson has promised to deliver Brexit by Hallowersquoen ldquodo or die, evenit means a no-deal that could boost support for the SNP and independence.Mr Hunt has said he believes in the Union ldquowith every fibre of my being, but has also set a no-deal deadline of September , saying he would be ready to take the UK out of Europe on WTO termsthere was no realistic chance by then of a renegotiated deal.Ahead of Mrs May speech, Mr Sturgeon predicted the Prime Ministerrsquos ultimate legacy would be Scottish independence.

title: mother-knew-glasgow-opens-linda-mccartney-show
story: A major retrospective of the photographic art of Linda McCartney, collected and curated by her family, has gone on display in Glasgowrsquos Kevingrove Art Gallery and Museum."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Linda McCartney retrospective at Kelvingrove","description": "Linda McCartney retrospective at Kelvingrove","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs sDfrMHfo-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests sDfrMHfo.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Video by Colin MearnsIt is the first time the exhibition of images - from showbusiness shots to intimate portraits of her husband, Sir Paul McCartney and children - has been shown in the UK.:Sir Paul McCartney on his late we Lindas photography ahead of Glasgow exhibitionThe show, called The Linda McCartney Retrospective, runs at the itself beloved museum until January.Sir Paul and his daughters Mary and Stella put together the show., a retrospective that includes one of her diaries from the s, displayed for the first time.The exhibition has previously been shown in Vienna, Seoul and Montpellier.Born in Scarsdale, New York, Linda McCartney studied art history at the University of Arizona.Her break came while working as an editorial assistant at Town and Country magazine.She used an unwanted invitation to a Rolling Stones promo party on the Hudson River to take pictures of the band and following the success of the images, she became a professional photographer.As the resident photographer at Fillmore East in New York, she took pictures of many of the greats: Otis Reading, BB King, The Doors, The Grateful Dead, Frank Zappa, The Who and Jimi Hendrix among others.In , Linda was voted US Female Photographer of the Year and soon afterwards became the first woman to have her work featured on the cover of Rolling Stone magazine with a portrait of Eric Clapton.Following her marriage, her work focused on the natural world, family le and social commentary.She continued to work prolically as a photographer until her death from breast cancer in . Her work has been exhibited by institutions including the International Center of Photography in New York, the Victoria  Albert Museum and the National Portrait Gallery in London.Themes in the show include The Sixties, Family Le, Self Portraits, Animals and Nature, People and Places, Making the Magic and Scotland, featuring pictures taken at the family home in Argyll and of people from local communities in Campbeltown, shape this signicant retrospective.She died from breast cancer in  at the age of .Sir Paul said: ldquoThe whole family loves to honour Lindarsquos work - she would have loved this because Glasgow was a place she loved.ldquoShe loved Scotland because it gave us a lot of fond memories, a lot of freedom and a lot of happy times.ldquoIt is nice to have all of that encapsulated in the Kelvingrove exhibition.Speaking to The Herald Magazine last week, Sir Paul, , reminisced about their time spent at High Park Farm near Campbeltown and what Scotland means to him and his family.:Yesterday director Danny Boyle on why we still love The BeatlesLooking through the photographs last week with The Herald, he said the family had been happy at their home in Scotland.ldquoVery much so, he said ldquoIt is funny because the first time I really heard anyone talk about it with a lot of fondness was John Lennon.ldquoHe had relatives up in Scotland who he liked a lot and he visited them when he was a kid. He would talk with great fondness of the crofts and the holidays hersquod had up in Scotland. So, there was always a nice feeling about it for me.ldquoThen, when I ended up getting the farm at Mull of Kintyre and going up there and spending some time, it had the same kind of resonance for me. Again, it was this fondness for the people and for the land. It constituted a form of freedom for us.ldquoWe could get away from all the things we normally did and just enjoy a lot of space. One thing about the farm was you could walk out at night and see  degrees of sky which you canrsquot do in a city.Sir Paul purchased High Park Farm in . The farmhouse, atop a hill overlooking Machrihanish Bay, came with  acres.He married Linda three years later.Stella McCartney, a celebrated fashion designer, said: ldquoThrough these images you meet the real mother I knew.ldquoYou see her raw and deep talent and passion for her art, photography.ldquoAhead of her time on every level, this mother-of-four still held her camera close like a companion, she captures the world around her through her eyes and this can be seen on the walls around the exhibition.ldquoHer humour, her love of family and nature and her moments framed with a slight surreal edge ... Scotland was one of her favourite places on Earth and so many images were taken there.The retrospective also includes one of Linda McCartneyrsquos diaries from the s and a selection of her cameras and photographic equipment.ldquoThere is the one of me on the fence with two of my kids, Sir Paul said.ldquoI think it captures the free spirit that we enjoyed when we came to Scotland. We escaped a lot of business stuff that was going on in London.ldquoThat picture shows the joy of being in the freedom of Scotland. The baby is Mary and the one hanging over the fence is my eldest daughter Heather.

title: snp-lodge-official-complaint-ofcom-jeremy-vine-show
story: Panellists were discussingBoris Johnsons campaign to become Prime Minister amidreports thathe didbecomeprime minister support for independence could surge.Paul Burrell, Princess Dianarsquos former butler, who appeared on the Channel  show saidthe report on a surge in Scottish independenceBoris became PM wasldquofood forNicola Sturgeon.This really has to be seen to be believed.I mean for goodness sakes...Scotland, by itself  How is it going to survive The Jeremy Vine show on Channel , th June .Part  : pic BYXOSbSCv:Twitter storm after lists on Jeremy Vine show claims Scotland could never survive aloneHe then made a comment about how Scotland could not survive going it alone stating:ldquoI mean, for goodness sake, Scotland, by itself  Howrsquos it going survive  It has hellipwhat does it have ...oil, and a monster in a lake,and...whisky.It is now understood that Ofcom has been contacted by the party afterChannel  ignored and failed to reply to emails from the party raising concerns.In their complaint, the SNP say the broadcast was in breach of sections . and . Ofcomrsquos broadcasting code, citing the lack of impartiality and Vinersquos insistence in continuing the discussion despite a lack of a pro-independence voice.Explaining the SNPrsquos decision to lodge an official complaint, Hannah Bardell MP, the SNPrsquos media spokesperson atWestminster, told our sister paper The National: ldquoThis was one of the most inaccurate discussions about Scotland and independence ever broadcast on network television.ldquoThatrsquos saying something given the level of nonsense Scottish audiences witnessed in the run-up to .ldquoWersquoll continue to work with journalists, editors and, where necessary as in this case, broadcasting regulators to make sure Scotlandrsquos voice is heard ndash they are duty bound to ensure their programmes have due accuracy and due impartiality, not serve up guff like this.:If this doesnt make you want Scottish independence, nothing will Readers hit out at Jeremy Vine showldquoUltimately the broadcasters are only harming themselves with embarrassing low-level output like this from Channel  ndash which will only make Scottish audiences switch over.A spokesperson for Channel  said: ldquoWe regularly cover questions around Scottish independence on our daily current affairs programme, reflecting a broad range of opinions and voices.ldquoThe comments expressed by the contributors in the programme reflect their personal viewpoints, not those of the channel.The comments made on the June  episodewere lambasted by viewers with some stating that the narrow-minded comments were an advert for Scottish independence.

title: couple-mark-marriage-milestone-faslane-naval-base-first-met
story: Alan Pitchfork was serving on the HMS Repulse submarine, based at Faslane in Argyll in the s when he met we-to-be Brenda, who was working as a radio operator.The -year-old former submariner said he ldquoinstantly fell in love with the young Wren when they met at the communication centre ndash and eventually decided to propose on the site.:Everyday le in UKs most contentious baseOn Friday, the couple from Knaresborough, North Yorkshire, ed to the naval base for the th anniversary celebration of the Continuous At Sea Deterrent .Mrs Pitchfork, , told PA: ldquoI think on the evening I was askedI wanted to go to the cinema with Alan and it was a film I wanted to see so we headed off for the cinema.ldquoThen he took me to a slightly dferent area and proposed to me, which is why this place is so special.ldquoI accepted his offer of marriage here, we married in Helensburgh, so wersquore celebrating  years of marriage and coming back to the place where it all started.ldquoI feel quite honoured to be here today.Mr Pitchfork said the area ldquohas changed tremendously over the  years.He added: ldquoItrsquos just wonderful to come back here after  years, see all the changes, it brings a lot of memories back for us both. We feel honoured.: years of nukes on the ClydeldquoI think the storyrsquos got around a little bit, wersquove had quite a few people mentioning it so we feel like celebrities, famous people, but wersquore not.When askedany of the submariners currently serving at the base had followed his example, he said: ldquoI havenrsquot had much chance to talk to any of the young guns yet but therersquos plenty of them so Irsquom sure it must happen.

title: jeremy-hunt-hints-blocking-independence-referendum-even-snp-win-majority
story: The Foreign Secretary repeatedly refused to rule out the possibility, and said the SNP ldquoneed to be true to what they promised about the  result settling the issue for a generation.He also suggested the First Minister was slacking over preparations for a no-deal Brexit, something her critics accuse of her doing in order to hasten independence.Mr Hunt said the SNP Government had been Scottish Government.Mr Hunt made the comments in a media briefing after meeting Tory activists in Perth ahead of the sole Scottish hustings in the Tory leadership contest.:SNP lodge an official complaint to Ofcom over Jeremy Vine showLast month, Mr Hunt said thatbecame PM he would set ldquothree stringent challenges to the SNP before they could hold another independence referendum.The first, ldquoIrsquom a democrat, and I remember that in that independence referendum, the SNP very clearly said that this would settle the outcome for a generation, and I think they need to be true to what they promised the Scottish electorate, just as we are being true to what we promised the British electorate in delivering Brexit.Mr Hunt said the Scottish Government had been ldquovery disappointing in their preparations for a no-deal Brexit, which none of us want, but any responsible government or authority in the United Kingdom should be taking seriously, because there is that risk.Pushed for This isnrsquot the time to go into details, but I think they know, and we know the areas where more could be done.SNP Finance Secretary Derek Mackay last year erted poundm of poundm in Brexit-related Barnett formula consequentials into other spending areas, and said he was unable to identy how much of a further pound.m for   would go on Brexit.Ruling out including the First Minister in his negotiating team with the EUhe is PM, he said: ldquoI want a Brexit that works for the Union. Irsquom a passionately committed Unionist, and Nicola Sturgeon is trying to break up that Union.ldquoSo I donrsquot believe that her role in any Brexit negotiations would be one that would help further or strengthened the Union, because she is fundamentally against that.ldquoI want to be clear that I would work constructively and positively and with an open-mind with the First Minister on every single issue that brings Scotland forward, but not on the issue of independence, where I profoundly disagree.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said: ldquoThis high-handed arrogance from Jeremy Hunt may appeal to the Tory faithful but it certainly wonrsquot appeal to the rest of Scotland.ldquoNo wonder support for the Tories has plummeted in Scotland - and no wonder support for independence is continuing to increase.:Jeremy Hunt wants Scotland to be a green Silicon ValleyldquoThe mandate to hold another independence referendum is not a matter of opinion ndash it is a matter of fact.He went on: ldquoJeremy Huntrsquos comments on a no-deal Brexit are gobsmacking ndash only a few days ago he admitted he was prepared to take the UK out of the EU without a deal, despite the enormous economic and social damage that this could inflict on the country, and now he is claiming we are not doing enough to fix his mess.ldquoThis is like an arsonist setting a building on fire and then complaining that the firefighters arenrsquot doing enough to tackle the blaze.ldquoThe SNP Scottish Government continues with its preparations to protect against the threats from Brexit, but no amount of preparation or funding can completely mitigate all the impacts of leaving the European Union - particularly a catastrophic no-deal Brexit.

title: scottish-labour-maximise-devolution-new-age-green-jobs
story: The Scottish Labour leader will tell a party event in Motherwell a Labour administration at Holyrood would ldquoexperiment with new forms of public bodies, andldquomaximise devolution to sustain jobs in a ldquogreen industrial revolution.Pointing towards more government borrowing, he will say: ldquoWe must be able to invest in our manufacturing base to make the transition we need. For this we need borrowing powers fit for a parliament.He will also accuse the SNP government of failing to use its current powers to prevent or mitigate Tory austerity and address wealth and health inequalities in Scotland.Mr Leonard will speak event alongside Midlothian MP Daniele Rowley and shadow business secretary Rebecca Long Bailey, who is tipped to succeed Jeremy Corbyn.He will say there is a need to ldquoexperiment in dferent forms of ownershiphellip so that we cease to be spectators or victims of circumstances, but participants and common owners.He will say: ldquoFor the avoidance of doubt, we will not attain the transformative change we need by leaving it to market forces. Or merely leaving it to the mitigation of market forces, through defensive rescues.ldquoIf we are to re-purpose the whole Scottish economy it cannot be done according to the central tenets of neo-liberal economics: the old ideas of privatisation, of austerity, of rolling back the state.Rather than relying on foreign investment or ldquomultinational financial and corporate interests, he will advocate ldquoan innovative state that uses its powers over procurement, planning, and licensing to drive low carbon and renewable energy developments.Mr Leonard, who has set up a working group on greater devolution, said he wanted more decisions made in Scotland, but did not want to undermine the Union.He said: ldquoWe are tapping into an understandinghellip that the UK state needs to be reformed.ldquoWe want to see the abolition of the House of Lords, and I want to see stronger regional and national governments with the UK as well.SNP MSP Richard Lyle said: ldquoLabour have been promising to abolish the House of Lords for decades, but they lack the backbone for any meaningful action.ldquoItrsquos hollow promises like these that explain exactly why people across Scotland have given up on Labour, and why theyrsquore polling in single figures.ldquoAs long as Labour allows Westminster to do whatever it wants to Scotland, theyrsquoll continue down the path to complete irrelevance.ldquoIf Labour want to stand a chance of recovery, they need to start standing up for the interests of the Scottish people ndash against Brexit, and for Scotland taking its future into its own hands.

title: funding-clarity-needed-end-confusion-free-nursery-places
story: The Scottish Governmentrsquos stated aim is to improve outcomes for children, especially those who are more vulnerable or disadvantaged and support parents to work, train or study.To this end ministers invested almost pound million of additional funding between  and  to expand funded early learning and childcare to  hours and the Government is gearing up for a signicant expansion with the new cost of delivering  hours from  estimated to be some poundm per year.This figure has already caused concern with councils, who have themselves estimated annual costs following the expansion to be about pound billion.Such a funding disparity is in itself a signicant concern and, as Audit Scotland pointed out, poses a signicant risk to the roll-out of the policy.As the latest report from the Scottish Government shows there is also a major issue for private nurseries - without whom the policy would be impossible to deliver.Despite the financial element of the policy being called ldquoFunding Follows the Child this is in fact somewhat disingenuous because funding is given first to councils, who then decide what portion to pass on to private nurseries.The report shows a signicant disparity between the hourly rates paid to nurseries in dferent parts of Scotland with the figure ranging from less then pound to more than pound.The good news is that hourly rates have increased in all local authority areas since  .But the bad news, according to the National Day Nurseries Association, is that the ying payments do not reflect the cost of delivering the places.As a survey by parent body Connect found last week many families are already struggling to access the full financial benefit of the policy and are having to pay private nurseries for additional hours, causing frustration and confusion.There is an urgent need to establish just how much the roll-out will actually cost and whether the available funding is enough to pay for it in both state and private nursery settings. Otherwise parents will once again face confusion over their new entitlement.

title: iraq-celebrates-babylon-named-unesco-world-heritage-site
story: The vote was held in Azerbaijan, years after Baghdad began campaigning for the site to be added to the list.The city on the Euphrates River is about  miles south of Baghdad and once was a main tourist attraction before Iraq suffered one war after another in the past four decades.# BREAKINGNew inscription on @UNESCO #WorldHeritage List: Babylon in #Iraq ##. Bravo! ### https:t.co thVmwrjX #WHC pic UXSJnwDUmdash UNESCOJuly , Babylon, , years old and now mainly an archaeological ruin with two important museums, is where dynasties have risen and fallen since the earliest days of settled human civilisation.King Hammurabi wrote his famous code of laws in Babylon, while Nebuchadnezzar sent his vast army from the city to Jerusalem to put down an uprising and bring the Jews back as slaves.Some say Alexander the Great, who led his army out of Macedonia to conquer most of the known world, died there in  BC.Dozens of Iraqis waving their national flag gathered at the Ishtar Gate at the site celebrating their cityrsquos new international status.Iraqi prime minister Adel Abdul-Mahdi described the vote as ldquoanother victory for the Iraq of civilisations that was and will always be a lighthouse to the world.President Barham Saleh tweeted that after Babylon, more ancient sites would be added to the list, through which ldquoIraq will restore that status that it deserves.Parliament speaker Mohammed al-Halbousi and minister of culture Abdul-Amir al-Hamadani congratulated the Iraqi people on the announcement.The vote came years after the Islamic State group damaged another Iraq World Heritage Site in the countryrsquos north, the ancient city of Hatra.The extremists also destroyed other sites in Iraq, including Nimrud where giant winged bulls that once stood sentry at the nearly ,-year-old palace were hacked to pieces.Along with Babylon and Hatra, Iraq has three other sites of world heritage, the archaeological city of Samarra in central Iraq, Ashur in the north and the citadel of the northern city of Erbil.Unesco said in its statement that Babylonrsquos ldquoremains, outer and inner-city walls, gates, palaces and temples, are a unique testimony to one of the most influential empires of the ancient world.ldquoThe cityrsquos association with one of the seven wonders of the ancient world ndash the Hanging Gardens ndash has also inspired artistic, popular and religious culture on a global scale, Unesco said.

title: us-pursue-citizenship-question-census-plan-unclear
story: It comes hours after President Donald Trump said he was ldquovery seriously considering an executive order to get the question on the form.The government has already begun the process of printing the census questionnaire without that question.The Trump administrationrsquos focus on asking broadly about citizenship for the first time since  reflects the enormous political stakes and potential costs in the once-a-decade population count that determines the allocation of seats in the House of Representatives for the next  years and the distribution of some  billion US dollarsin federal spending.It also reflects Mr Trumprsquos interest in reshaping how congressional districts are drawn.The News Reports about the Department of Commerce dropping its quest to put the Citizenship Question on the Census is incorrect or, to state it dferently, FAKE! We are absolutely moving forward, as we must, because of the importance of the answer to this question.mdash Donald J. TrumpJuly , Districts are currently based on the total population, but some Republicans want them based on the population of eligible voters, a change that could disadvantage Democrats by excluding immigrants.The Supreme Court has left open the issue of whether districts based only on the population of eligible voters is constitutional.The Census Bureaursquos own experts have said a citizenship question would discourage immigrants from participating in the survey and result in a less accurate census that would redistribute money and political power away from Democratic-led cities where immigrants tend to cluster to whiter, rural areas where Republicans do well.Mr Trump, speaking as he departed the White House for a weekend in New Jersey, said he might take executive action.ldquoItrsquos one of the ways that wersquore thinking about doing it, very seriously, he said.An executive order would not, by itself, override court rulings blocking the inclusion of the citizenship question.But such an action from Mr Trump would perhaps give administration lawyers a new basis to try to convince federal courts that the question could be included.ldquoExecutive orders do not override decisions of the Supreme Court, Thomas Saenz, president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defence and Educational Fund, said in a statement on Friday. The organisation is representing plaintfs in the census lawsuit in Maryland.Later on Friday, Justice Department lawyers formally told US District Judge George Hazel in Maryland that the administration was not giving up the legal fight to add the citizenship question to the next census. But they also said it was unclear how they would proceed, according to a court filing.ldquoThey still say they donrsquot have clear instructions on what to do, said Mr Saenz, who took part in a conference call with the judge and lawyers for both sides in one of three lawsuits seeking to keep the question off the census. The other two are in New York and Calornia.The judge had expressed mounting frustration with the mixed signals the administration was sending, first telling him on Tuesday that the question was off only to have Mr Trump tweet the next day that the administration was ldquoabsolutely moving forward with efforts to include the question.On Friday evening, the American Civil Liberties Union asked a federal judge in New York to permanently block the administration from adding the citizenship question to the  census.

title: rab-mcneil-let-39-s-get-back-high-old-time-town-centres
story: Back in those ancient times there was commerce for sure, but also performances, oratory and public discussion. Today, the threat to the ldquohigh street is all about shops, as it is shopping that now defines us. We are consumers, ever exhorted to consume more, and implicitly castigated now for doing it in all the wrong places. That is to say, online, or perhaps in out-of-town malls.This week, the high street minister ndash therersquos a high street minister  who knew  does he cover Scotland  who knows  ndash Jake Berry exhorted punters to stop watching box-sets and get off their butts to waddle forth into the high street, there to spend money on clothes, coffee and, er ndash since itrsquos pretty much all thatrsquos there ndash more clothes and more coffee.It seemed a somewhat inept demand, since we watch box-sets in the evening when the shops are closed, but it was ostensibly prompted by a poll showing that less than half of the apparently important - age group visited the high street every week.I found the idea that they ought to do so quite peculiar since, when I lived in Edinburgh, I never visited the ldquohigh street ndash or city centre ndash from one year to the next.Parking places were few and hideously expensive I never had the massive pile of change necessary for the bus and, besides, the city had authorised large malls and open-air shopping venues on the outskirts of town, where parking was free and plentul, and a chap could stravaig from shop A to shop B without being molested by chuggers, buskers and indigent inebriates.Itrsquos always busy in Union Street and in the nearby malls, so whatrsquos behind the ldquodeath of the high street is a bit of a mystery, eventhe culprit is usually revealed as business rates.At any rate, Mr Berry announced the launch of a high street task force this week, which amounts to experts ndash aye, thaim ndash advising cooncils about how to breathe new le into toon centres.Other great minds have been whirring incessantly and one of these, belonging to Mr B. Johnson, a British leadership contender, came up with a great solution: Brexit, after which everything on the high street will be just dandy. Phew, glad we cleared that one up.Amazon, which is largely blamed for the decline of the high street, is also doing its bit, with the launch of pop-up shops putting new small business on the high street. Itrsquos something at least, but by definition ersatz and impermanent. I may be wrong , but I think we appreciate solidity, ken Thatrsquos why itrsquos disturbing to read about institutions like Boots, Debenhams and even Markies closing stores.If yoursquod have taken the Forum out of Rome yoursquod have taken the heart out of the place. The same goes for ldquohigh streets. Ironically, many newspapers , government offices and big stores moved out of town centres, creating a feeling that le was where, often on soulless industrial estates.Banks and post offices have gone. Grocerrsquos  Donrsquot be daft. But herersquos a plan: bring rsquoem back. Provide free daytime buses in from the suburbs. Put on proper free concerts in large, green public areas. Honestly, we want to come back, to get away from the computer screen and oot the hoose.But we want to feel welcome and comfortable. We want to make a day of it. We donrsquot just want to shop ndash because wersquore more than just consumers.++++LIKE most patriotic Scots I was rooting for England in the womenrsquos World Cup football tournament. So it was a shame when they went out to the USA.It was also a shame to see the scorer of the winning American goal mimicking the drinking of tea in her celebrations.As a dig at English moreacutes, it seemed woefully out of date as most Englanders these days ndash like most Scots ndash would rather have a creamy frostino, but I guess you could also make a case for it being harmless, even amusing, certainly compared to male footballer celebrations, which often involve irresponsibly taunting opposition fans.Personally, I deplore all the silly dances and heavy petting that now follow a goal. Perhaps itrsquos because Irsquom not an exuberant person.Were I to score the winning goal in a cup final ndash something I dream about hourly ndash then I would permit myself a wry smile before accepting a couple of manly handshakes and then ing to my own half timeously so that the other side might have a sporting chance of evening the score.That said,I were on a massive bonus for scoring, I might indulge in a triple-somersault and some light snogging.++++AS regular readers know, I spend large parts of my day thinking about what should happen to my body after Irsquom deid.I wonrsquot be leaving it to medical science, and certainly not to students that they might poke aboot in it. Neither do I want it cremated, as Irsquove a feeling that might still hurt a bit.I think the last time we discussed this issue, wersquod narrowed the choice down to being tied in a hessian sack and bunged under a tree, or put into a cylinder until Irsquod turned into compost, which might then be used to fertilise the soil. As Irsquove often been likened to a kind of fertiliser in the past, that does seem apt.This week, with graveyards and crematoria now choc-a-bloc, John Ashton, former president of the Faculty of Public Health, suggested that the sides of motorways, cycle paths or even former industrial sites could be used to house the dead.Not me, mate. Imagine the noise at the side of a road. As for cycle paths, Irsquod only consider thatI could haunt the people who use them. Nope, when it comes to burial, Irsquod prefer to have a tree on ma heid.++++LIKE most decent ratepayers, Irsquod consider a trip to the Glastonbury Festival a terrible punishment. Irsquove been to one pop festival, that one in Feand, in a surprise development, I hated every minute of it.I was sent thither in the line of duty and recall little of the experience beyond impudent delinquents tittering at my Tupperware box of sandwiches, a mob forming on the suspicion that I was an undercover police officer , and the fact that, this being Scotland, everyone seemed to be drunk.I thought these events were supposed to be all about drugs. If so, in Scotland, the drug of choice seemed not to be heroin or cocaine, but Buckfast.If yoursquoll permit me to be candid, Irsquoll confess that I spend a large part of my leisure hours inebriated. But I prefer to do so in the privacy of my own home where therersquos less chance of arrest or marriage.Why anyone would wish to get drunk in a place where home is a tent and the lavatory a metal shed overflowing with dubious fluids, I will never know. And as for that awful music hellipRead more: Give folk free pants and theyd still snf them with suspicion

title: letters-let-us-citizens-assemblies-matters-independence
story: However, all is not lost. Maybe the idea will be salvagedCitizens Assemblies are piloted in less contentious areas of public policy, for example, assisted dying, or the decriminalisation of drugs, or maybe even the ision of school children on the grounds of their parents religions. Or whether disruptive and provocative marches such as those held by All Under One Banner and the Orange Order have any place in modern Scotland.Or would that be going too far Peter A Russell, Glasgow G.NICOLA Sturgeon tells us that Scotland is "heading inexorably towards independence". That will be why she is holding citizens assemblies to advise her on the way forward for Scotland  By doing so, she clearly wants informed and unbiased opinions about her project, and will accept a verdict against separatismthat is what the Citizens Assembly advises.Sorry, I donrsquot know how I could have said such a silly thing.Jill Stephenson, Edinburgh EH.REBECCA McQuillan suggests a ldquoUK Citizens Assembly would let Scots ldquoexplain to their English friends what it really means to be Scottish . But our Government has already explained this, and suggested many ways we could reach compromise to adapt Englandrsquos choices to Scotlandrsquos needs. Nobodyrsquos listening. Nobodyrsquos interested. A UK Citizensrsquo Assembly would be no dferent.Itrsquos time we were governed by people who are interested in us because they live among us, and who have to take account of our needs because we elect them.Mary McCabe, Glasgow G.THERE is something of the tragi-comical when the SNP is accused of a ldquodrip-feed of anti-UK propaganda day in and day out, by someone who outmatches that with his own regular torrent of rhetoric and invective. I refer to Keith Howell .There is never anything substantive or consequential about his approach. For example, it can come as no surprise that the SNP regards devolution as a stepping stone towards independence ndash that is the target, not, as Mr Howell claims, the break-up of the UK. Goodness me, currently there are plenty of iniduals within the Unionist cause who are streaks ahead of the SNP on that front. Regarding alleged SNP failures, these are replicated in spades in the public sector south of the Border ndash and we are thirled to what happens there.Mr Howell repeats endlessly the flaws the SNP has, but never promotes any other cause, or any alternative party as an improvement. He does not realise that in criticising the SNP in the way he does, he demeans the integrity of the majority of Scots who troop out in election after election, to vote SNP in numbers unachievable by any other party. For example, at Westminster, the Scottish Conservatives have a desultory  MPs out of , while the SNP have  ndash nearly three times that number. The Tories are going nowheretheir sole purpose is to obsess about ldquoindependence or ldquoseparation ndash  times in a single electoral leaflet ndash as they did, with no reference whatsoever to what their vision is for Scotland under a Conservative regime. Perhaps Mr Howell could help them out with his own solutions to their dilemma. The problem he, and they, have is that this parish council of Holyroodrequires full independence ndash in the same way that factions in England are now claiming that Brexit delivers its independence. In what way does Mr Howell consider that Scotland would fit into the Union when that happens Douglas R Mayer, Currie.TWO millionaires vying to be PM by out-Brexiting the other, elected by , or so white middle-class votes. Jeremy Hunt betrays he would reverse the fox hunting ban . Good news for the English landed gentry. As this is devolved in Scotland the Scottish landed folk will just have to wait, at least for the time being. After all neither cares that Scotland voted  per cent Remain so why make a distinction between English and Scottish foxes  Now at a Tory fundraiser in London, for pound,, a rich Tory benefactor, wins a hunting trip to Scotland to shoot cage reared birds bred solely to let some gun-toting numpty shoot them .Speaking of numpties, Alexander Boris de Peffel Johson has ponticated that a pound spent in Croydon is of far more value to the country than a pound spent in Strathclyde and he has pronounced that as Prime Minister he will crown himself saviour and minister for the Union. The choice of course is not ours to make and is truly the stuff of nightmares but I say, on balance, go for it Boris.Christine Grahame,SNP MSP, the Scottish Parliament, Edinburgh.THERESA May warns her successor not to trust Nicola Sturgeon. Hmm, is this the same person who promised ldquostrong and stable government Steve Barnet, Gargunnock.I NOTE ALAN Simpsons article .Mr Simpson writes: ldquoAll this about a film charting events in  and which is known by every Scottish primary school pupil. This may be the case, but in my time no Scottish history was taught in Scottish schools we were told about Magna Carta, but not the Declaration of Arbroath. Mind you, I appreciate that things have changed since I was in school, I left in .His comments seem dismissive of the story of Wallace and Bruce, yet England coveted Scotland and the English Crown held it by force of arms England was always seeking to expand its boundaries and even claimed the throne of France ndash only ceding defeat when the French started to guillotine their Royalty.It is worth noting that the war with England was fought on Scottish soil the great men Mr Simpson talks of would not have existed in a Greater England.Jim Lynch, Edinburgh.Read more: Letters: SNPs talking shop is pointless

title: hundreds-tory-members-sent-two-leadership-election-ballot-papers
story: The BBC, citing a party source, said more than , people could have multiple forms in the contest between Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt.It added those affected could include people who joined their local Conservative party at their home and work address or others who have changed their name.The party told the broadcaster members will be clear that anyone voting twice will be expelled.Former Cabinet minister Sir Patrick McLoughlin, who is chairing Mr Huntrsquos campaign, said the issue has ldquogot to be looked at but said he expected Tory members to follow the rules and vote just once.Sir Patrick, a former Conservative chairman, told the BBCrsquos Today programme: ldquoItrsquos made very clear on the ballot paper that you are only allowed to vote once. I expect Conservative members to follow that.ldquoIf people have joined two associations they may get two ballot papers. I get two ballot papers in elections because I am on two dferent sets of electoral registers, it doesnrsquot mean that I vote twice, I donrsquot.He added: ldquoIt canrsquot be clearer, itrsquos right there on the ballot paper saying that you must only vote on one occasion and I expect people to do that.The vote closes on July  and the result will be revealed a day later.Theresa May will take her final session of Prime Ministerrsquos Questions on July  and hand over to the contest winner that afternoon.

title: aberdeenshire dancers head to holyrood
story: A collection of Aberdeenshire#s finest Highland Dancers are heading to the Scottish Parliament to help celebrate its th Anniversary.The dancers will help entertain guests in a fun-filled day at Holyrood on Saturday, June .A whole host of activities will take place on the day including live music and dance, retro games, and a rare opportunity to go behind the scenes of the Parliament and sit in the Presiding Officer’s seat.Sessions will be hosted on ‘The Future of Scotland’ where guests can remotely control robots of the future, experience D Holograms, or discuss their aspirations for Scotland for the next  years.There will also be  debates, including a Festival of Politics session which discusses the concept of ‘Happiness’.Looking ahead to the event, the Parliament’s Presiding Officer, the Rt Hon Ken Macintosh MSP said: “Our focus has always been for this Parliament to be open and accessible for all and what better opportunity to open our doors than for our th Anniversary celebrations.“There truly is something for everyone as we celebrate our birthday and play host to the best of Scottish culture."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.mearnsleader webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The asset transfer bid for the mill is facing refusal"  Mill asset transfer facing refusal viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie firm to host charity event
story: Just a few tickets remain for a fundraising event in aid of Charlie House#s Big Build Appeal which will take place in Inverurie on Friday .During , Inverurie-based asset cleaning and decontamination solutions specialist company Denholm MacNamee has pledged to raise £, in support of the Charlie House Big Build Appeal.The aim of the appeal is to raise funds to build a state-of-the-art specialist support centre that will provide a wide range of services to babies, children and young people with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions, and their families, in the North East of Scotland.The total raised by the company so far is expected to take a major step forward on Friday when Inverurie’s Drouthy Laird is the setting for a quiz night and disco.Teams of up to six are invited to enter at a cost of £ per person.The evening will also feature a raffle and two auctions – one of which will benefit Denholm MacNamee’s parent organisation’s concurrent fundraising campaign on behalf of Glasgow’s Royal Hospital for Children.Top prizes in the raffle include a Hugo Boss watch donated by Sinclairs, £ courtesy of Logie Country House and a £ voucher for Slaters.
